Matt wrote:

>  > The use of setUp() is irrelevant for our purpose.
>  >
> 
> Is setUp() not used to set up fixtures?  how is setUp() irrelevant
> to this discussion?

It is irrelevant to the discussion only because it is an implementation 
detail: it is just a framework method that xUnit invokes. The salient 
point is that the instance variables of the TestCase class implement the 
fixture.

> <snip/>
> 
>  >Yes, but the object that contains them is a fixture. And every such
> 
> Here you say a fixture is an 'object'

It is.

>  > object instantiated from the same class embodies that fixture. As
> a
>  > result, the class itself, being a blueprint for those objects,
> embodies
>  > that fixture. Therefore, the test case class and the fixture are
>  > conceptually the same. The test case class is merely an expression
> of
>  > the fixture.
> 
> Here you seem to say that the fixture is a class. 
> assertEquals(class,object);
> 
> will that fail?

As I wrote in my comment to Ron, it is common shorthand to say a 
collection has a property when all the elements in the collection have 
that property.

I also clarified, I think rather exceedingly:

  * TestCase object <=> fixture
  * TestCase class <=> fixture definition

When all the objects in a class are the same -- because they all have 
the same state when initialized -- it may be convenient to refer to "the 
class" as shorthand for "any instance of the class."

>  > Was it really necessary to write all that? I am not J J Sylvester.
> I
>  > have no interest in proving everything I know to you from first
> principles.
>  >
>  > > My apologies to the wider world for starting this absurd thread;
> I was
>  > > just trying to be helpful to the enquirer.
>  >
>  > No, you weren't. Now that you have established a pattern, I feel I
> have
>  > solid ground on which to say this. You were being antagonistic, as
> you
>  > have often been, by pretending not only to know it all, but that
>  > everyone else is therefore incorrect. As I am often accused of
>  > pretending to know it all -- and sometimes guilty of it -- I
> surely know
>  > the signs.
> 
> I am a newbie to this discussion group (obviously) and am just
> learning Java and JUnit.. and I can tell you that what Jim is saying
> is what is being taught at University level now.  Before you
> click 'reply' let me state that I fully understand that University
> and the 'real world' are VERY different worlds.  However in defense
> of Jim, I have several times considered looking for a different
> group to follow about JUnit because of you J.B.  You may be King of
> Programmers but your attitude doesn't fit well in a discussion
> community.  I am new to Java but not new to the collaborative
> community of news and discussion groups.  Let's learn from each
> other just as I have learned from all of you guys who know way more
> about this stuff than I ever will.  But keep in mind, stepping on
> someone else never makes you any taller. 

I am not King of Programmers, nor have I ever claimed to be. This is the 
kind of nonsense that I've seen far too much of recently, and frankly, 
I'm getting very tired of it -- and yet /I/ am the one with the 
attitude. /You/ are the one presuming to know what I'm thinking, not I you.

I don't understand this talk about "my attitude" -- and I am being 
direct and honest. I have managed to and continue to collaborate 
extremely effectively with many (most?) of the members of this group and 
the other XP/Agile-related groups, so there are few possibilities.

  * I am in a protracted, bad mood and letting it show
  * You misunderstand my attitude

....I'm sure there are others, but no more come to mind. Do note that I 
am not saying that either of those is more likely than the other. I'm 
just trying to find as many interpretations for what's going on as 
possible. I have just run dry quickly.

I feel that some people step on me, and you feel that I step on others, 
so I guess it's all a question of perspective, isn't it? Perhaps we're 
all right.
--
